Executive Summary

RAPAC, LP Plant 95 in Memphis, Tennessee - RMP Facility ID#1000 0021 1889

October 2020, Update Resubmission



Site Information

RAPAC LP ("RAPAC") operates as a manufacturer of expandable polystyrene (EPS) beads (loose fill packaging material) in Oakland, Tennessee (NAICS 32614). The facility has one 12,000-gallon aboveground storage tank onsite containing isopentane (C.A.S.# 78-78-4) which is used in the formulation of the packaging products. The tank is located inside a concrete dike with capacity to hold approximately 34,000-gallons. 

The facility previously operated a total of three aboveground storage tanks, (2- 12,000-gallon and 1- 6,000-gallon capacity), prior to the decommissioning of two tanks (one 12,000-gallon and the 6,000-gallon) in 2020.  

Accident Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

RAPAC is committed to providing a safe working environment. We will achieve this mission by promoting a culture in which employee safety is paramount in each and every endeavor. We will actively promote and maintain the following beliefs in everything we do:



?    Safety performance is critically important to the success of RAPAC. 

?    Concern for employee safety will be evident and embedded into all phases of our work by design and through the business decisions that we make. 

?    Each employee is empowered with responsibility for his or her personal safety and the safety of their fellow employees and stakeholders. 

?    Continuous improvement is a way of life at RAPAC; we use feedback and experience to refine and build upon our culture to ensure continual forward progress. 

?    Safety incidents are preventable; we will strive to ensure that our policies, practices, and decisions are proactive on all accounts.

?    Management is responsible for ensuring employees have the knowledge, skills, and equipment necessary to protect themselves and others. 

?    We will not be satisfied to simply meet safety compliance standards. 

?    Every task must be

performed with concern for the welfare of ourselves, fellow employees, our contractors, our visitors, and the community in which we operate. 



Roles and responsibilities have been assigned by the RAPAC's senior management, have established accountability and have delegated authority to implement an effective safety management system. So that the system works effectively, each person within the company must understand his/her roles and responsibilities for the overall program management and for each individual program. The success of our program depends on all employees incorporating our culture into every part of our day-to-day business practice and decisions.



Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

RAPAC has developed and compiled a comprehensive set of operating procedures to provide instruction in the safe operation of facility processes covered by this risk management plan.  Procedures provide a reliable and consistent reference for all phases of process operations. 



Each procedure contains procedure steps, operating parameters and limits, safety and health hazard information, safety control measures, and assignment of responsibility for performing the procedure.  Operating procedures are kept current through the management of change process.



The Operations Manager and Maintenance Manager bear responsibility for developing, reviewing, and approving operating procedures.  The Maintenance Manager is responsible for correctly implementing operating procedures.



Emergency Response Program

The RAPAC plant is not required to establish and implement a community emergency action plan to handle releases; however, the plant maintains an internal emergency action plan containing specific procedure for prompt response to emergencies that impact property and personnel onsite. 

Periodic compliance audits will ensure that the plan is kept up-to-date. All employees are trained on this plan during new-hire training and receive

refresher training on a routine basis.

The RAPAC plant maintains a working relationship with the City of Oakland Fire Department, the Fayette County Fire Department, and the Fayette County Emergency Management Agency. These agencies are knowledgeable regarding the risks associated with the pentane system and response procedures during an emergency.  On April 3, 2019, these three agencies attended a tour and meeting at the plant to discuss emergency response needs.



RAPAC has no planned changes to improve safety at this time.
